Expectation1: Complete any assignments or tasks given by the mentor.
Situation1: The mentor assigned a code sample to be finished before the next meeting in three days.
Situation2: They skim a recent pharmacy newsletter while on break to see what new drugs have been released.
Story: I sat in the cramped break room, my laptop open to the code sample my mentor had assigned. The deadline was in three days, and I could already hear his voice in my head, reminding me how important it was to show progress. My fingers hovered over the keyboard, but my mind kept drifting to the pharmacy newsletter I’d just started skimming. There was a new drug release, and I knew my manager expected me to be up-to-date, ready to answer questions from both patients and colleagues. I felt the weight of both roles pressing down on me—my mentor’s trust in my commitment, my professional duty to stay informed. The minutes of my break ticked by, and I wrestled with the urge to dive deeper into the newsletter, fearing I’d miss something crucial for my job, while the unfinished code glared at me, a silent accusation. My heart pounded as I tried to decide which expectation to meet first, feeling the stress of being pulled in two directions at once.
